text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
--The High Court opens begins hearing a suit by 10 Danish citizens claiming that the country's EU treaties violate the national constitution.
--Some 39,000 businesses are claiming employment levy rebates but tax authorities say that a proportion of the requests are unrealistic.

--Danish time limits for appeals against tax assesments contravene human rights agreements and an unknown number of taxpayers could well be owed money by tax authorities, warns a Danish judge at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.
--Denmark's International Health Insurance has become the first in the country to offer instant travel insurance on the internet, paid for by credit card.
--One in five Danes will suffer clinical depression in the course of their lives and at any given time 200,000 are in a condition requiring treatment.
--Carlsberg is the leading foreign beer in Japan's most fashionable bars and restaurants, with sales growth of 20 percent last year.
--Small Danish shipbuilders are in trouble because the major yards are passing problems of falling contract prices down to sub-contractors.
--A survey shows insurance company Tryg-Baltica giving the best returns on pension plans.
